title: Murder of Jessie Earl
summary: Examines the 1980 disappearance and murder of Jessie Earl in Eastbourne, England. Her skeletal remains were discovered nine years after she vanished, raising haunting questions about a potential serial killer.
utterances: Jessie Earl disappeared from her seaside town in 1980 and wasn’t found for years.
Her remains painted a story of violence and secrecy.
Is her killer connected to the infamous Bible John?
transcript: When Jessie Earl failed to return home, her family knew something was wrong. Decades later, her bones were found, and a string of unsolved murders in the area began to look less like coincidences. This episode explores police missteps, missed connections, and the dark figure of a possible serial predator.

title: The Cathy Woods Case
summary: Explores the wrongful conviction of Cathy Woods for the murder of Michelle Mitchell in Nevada, USA. The truth unraveled through DNA evidence decades later.
utterances: Cathy Woods was the longest-serving wrongfully imprisoned woman in U.S. history.
Her confession raised red flags from the start.
Science would eventually free her.
transcript: Michelle Mitchell was killed in 1976, and Cathy Woods, a psychiatric patient, was convicted largely on her confession. The case was reopened much later, and exoneration came thanks to DNA advances and the tenacity of new investigators.

title: The Death of Stephen Port's Victims
summary: Delves into the crimes of Stephen Port, a London serial killer who targeted men he met on dating apps and poisoned them with GHB.
utterances: Stephen Port's victims were found within a small radius in East London.
Police failed to connect the dots between the four young men.
Dating apps provided Port with easy access to his victims.
transcript: Between June 2014 and September 2015, four men were found dead near Port’s apartment. The killer staged overdoses, but families and friends of the victims would not give up. The tragic story shines a light on police bias, flaws, and the power of community pressure.

title: The Kim Wall Murder
summary: Investigates the murder of Swedish journalist Kim Wall, who died aboard a homemade submarine owned by Danish inventor Peter Madsen.
utterances: Kim Wall was last seen boarding Madsen’s submarine in Copenhagen.
Her dismembered body was soon discovered washed up at sea.
The investigation quickly focused on Madsen’s strange and disturbing past.
transcript: Award-winning journalist Kim Wall went off to interview Peter Madsen for a new feature, but what followed stunned Scandinavia. The ensuing search for Wall, evidence hidden at sea, and Madsen's conflicting stories captivated and horrified the world.

title: The Heywood Murder
summary: Looks at the 2012 murder of Neil Heywood, a British businessman found dead in China, and the subsequent international political scandal.
utterances: Neil Heywood was found dead in his hotel room in Chongqing.
The investigation implicated high-profile Chinese politicians.
The case exposed deep corruption in the Chinese Communist Party.
transcript: Heywood’s death originally looked like alcohol poisoning, but a deeper investigation revealed cyanide and political intrigue reaching into the heart of Chinese power. The trials and propaganda campaign that followed captivated international audiences.

title: The Backpacker Murders
summary: Focuses on Ivan Milat, Australia's most infamous serial killer, who murdered and buried several backpackers in Belanglo State Forest.
utterances: Backpackers went missing in New South Wales during the 1990s.
The gruesome discoveries led police to Ivan Milat.
Milat never confessed to his crimes.
transcript: Ivan Milat lured travelers with the promise of rides and adventure, only to subject them to unimaginable violence. The detective work that led to his arrest became a legend of Australian policing.

title: Death of Bijan Ebrahimi
summary: Examines the racially motivated murder of Bijan Ebrahimi in Bristol, England, and subsequent failures of the police to protect him.
utterances: Ebrahimi was brutally murdered by his neighbors after years of harassment.
He made dozens of calls to police before his death.
A culture of disbelief left him vulnerable.
transcript: This tragic case exposed systemic racism at the heart of UK institutions. Police were called many times to help Ebrahimi but failed to intervene when he needed protection most.

title: Death Row Granny
summary: Tells the story of serial killer Velma Barfield, known as 'Death Row Granny', who poisoned six people during the 1970s.
utterances: Velma Barfield was the first woman executed in the U.S. after the death penalty was reinstated.
Her crimes shocked her quiet town.
She maintained her Christian faith even after conviction.
transcript: Barfield poisoned a string of partners and family members, always evading detection. Her legal battles and alleged repentance became a national debate on capital punishment and gender.

title: Disappearance of Claudia Lawrence
summary: Covers the mysterious 2009 disappearance of chef Claudia Lawrence in York, England—a case plagued by dead-ends and bungled leads.
utterances: Claudia Lawrence was last seen heading to work at the University of York.
Despite media interest, police have failed to solve the case.
Speculation about her private life led to victim-blaming.
transcript: Lawrence’s case remains a British tabloid sensation. Her personal life became public fodder, distracting from crucial early clues that might have solved her disappearance.

title: The Acid Bath Murders
summary: Unravels the story of John George Haigh, a serial killer in 1940s London who disposed of his victims in vats of acid.
utterances: Haigh gained the trust of wealthy victims before murdering them.
His methods led police on a macabre investigation.
The media dubbed him 'the Acid Bath Murderer.'
transcript: Haigh's method, dissolving the bodies in acid, allowed him to believe he could get away with murder. But property transactions and a victim's dog eventually brought the scheme crashing down.

title: The Bega Schoolgirl Murders
summary: Explores the 1997 abduction and murder of Lauren Barry and Nichole Collins by two men in New South Wales, Australia.
utterances: The girls were abducted on a Friday night after a party.
Mass searches failed to find them alive.
A witness testimony cracked the case.
transcript: Barry and Collins went missing after leaving a friend’s house. The community and police searched intensely before dark revelations emerged. The heart-wrenching details haunted Australia for decades.

title: Murder at White House Farm
summary: Dissects the UK’s famous White House Farm case, where Jeremy Bamber was convicted of murdering five family members in 1985.
utterances: At first, police thought Sheila Caffell had killed her parents and children.
The evidence slowly pointed elsewhere.
The trial divided a nation.
transcript: What appeared to be a familicide by Sheila Caffell unraveled in the aftermath of forensic investigations. The shock of Bamber’s conviction lingered—and debates rage on about guilt and motive.

title: Killer Nurse Beverly Allitt
summary: Investigates the shocking case of UK pediatric nurse Beverly Allitt, convicted of murdering and harming young children in her care in 1991.
utterances: Beverly Allitt exploited her role as a trusted NHS caregiver.
Her attacks on children stunned the village of Grantham.
Psychological motives remain debated.
transcript: Allitt’s quiet library assistant persona masked a dark secret. Media dubbed her the 'Angel of Death' after the murder trial, and her case remains a cautionary tale of institutional trust betrayed.

title: The Essex Boys
summary: Tells the violent story of the Rettendon murders in Essex, England, in which three drug dealers were gunned down in a Range Rover.
utterances: An underworld feud ended in a muddy farm track mass shooting.
Legend says the murders were an inside job.
Police corruption and retribution rumors abound.
transcript: The Rettendon Range Rover murders have been retold in film, books, and pub stories. The combination of gangland betrayal and unanswered questions makes it one of England’s most enduring crime legends.

title: The Copenhagen Fireplace Murder
summary: Unravels the macabre story of Peter Lundin, who murdered and dismembered his partner and her two sons in Denmark.
utterances: Police found burned body parts hidden in a fireplace.
Lundin’s brutal past had already shocked the US.
His trial was international news.
transcript: Peter Lundin killed in both America and Denmark. His disturbing behavior and courtroom confessions made him an infamous name in international true crime.

title: Death on the Orient Express
summary: Examines the murder of Robert Farquharson, who drove his car into a dam on Father’s Day 2005—killing his three children.
utterances: Farquharson’s trial asked if the tragedy was accident or murder.
The case shocked all of Australia.
Many questioned the justice system afterward.
transcript: Parental murder is among the rarest of crimes. This episode discusses the psychological toll of the case, police investigation flaws, and the legacy of pain left behind.

title: The Killing of Lynette Dawson
summary: Investigates the prolonged disappearance and suspected murder of Australian mother Lynette Dawson, a case made famous by the podcast 'The Teacher’s Pet.'
utterances: Lynette’s husband waited weeks to report her missing.
Chris Dawson’s relationship with a student cast suspicion.
The podcast reignited the cold case.
transcript: For years, rumors swirled about Lyn Dawson’s fate. Few leads, police inaction, and dramatic revelations in later media coverage made it iconic—and led to new trials decades later.

title: The Kray Twins
summary: Unpacks the story of Ronnie and Reggie Kray, famous London gangsters whose crimes and legends defined the British underworld.
utterances: The Krays were Britain’s most notorious criminal brothers.
They ran nightclubs and rackets in 1960s London.
Their capture and trial were front-page news.
transcript: With a mix of celebrity, violence, and social power, the Krays’ story is as much about British postwar identity as crime. Their eventual downfall was a mixture of courage by law enforcement and the Krays’ own extravagance.

title: The Moorside Mystery
summary: Explores the abduction of Shannon Matthews, and the extraordinary hoax that shocked the UK.
utterances: Nine-year-old Shannon vanished walking home from school.
Media coverage echoed the earlier Madeleine McCann case.
The kidnap plot’s mastermind stunned police and the public.
transcript: From a missing-person panic to the truth behind the Matthews family’s hoax, this case revealed the depths of exploitation and media frenzy.

title: The Murder of Rachel Nickell
summary: Dissects the infamous 1992 Wimbledon Common slaying, the hunt for her real killer, and a notorious police botched investigation.
utterances: Rachel Nickell was attacked in broad daylight in front of her child.
Police entrapped an innocent man using an undercover psychologist.
The real killer confessed years later.
transcript: This murder case haunted British society for years, as the wrong person was publicly accused and only DNA technology would ultimately reveal the actual perpetrator.

title: The Bathtub Killer
summary: Profiles Dale Devon Scheanette, who raped and murdered women in Texas, leaving his victims in bathtubs.
utterances: Scheanette’s crimes left a signature that stumped police for a decade.
DNA forensics finally sealed his fate.
Survivor stories brought him to justice.
transcript: The Bathtub Killer targeted women living alone, breaking in and attacking them in their own homes. Undetected for years, his reign of terror ended when survivors gave critical testimony and advances in DNA evidence built an airtight case.

title: The Death of Billie-Jo Jenkins
summary: Investigates the perplexing unsolved murder of 13-year-old Billie-Jo Jenkins in Hastings, England, in 1997.
utterances: Billie-Jo was found bludgeoned on her foster parents’ patio.
Multiple trials only deepened the mystery.
The case remains officially unsolved.
transcript: Billie-Jo’s death generated a media storm. Failed prosecutions, dubious witness claims, and intriguing new evidence raised more questions than answers.

title: The Killing of Reeva Steenkamp
summary: Covers the 2013 murder of model Reeva Steenkamp by Olympic athlete Oscar Pistorius in South Africa.
utterances: Oscar Pistorius shot Reeva through a locked bathroom door.
The trial captured headlines worldwide.
Domestic violence and celebrity shaped the case’s narrative.
transcript: Pistorius claimed self-defense, but prosecutors argued it was premeditated murder. Media and the public grappled with disability, privilege, and gender even as the court weighed the conflicting testimonies.

title: The Croydon Cat Killer
summary: Delves into the mass mutilation of cats in South London and how social panic, media, and police investigation unsettled the UK.
utterances: Hundreds of mutilated cats were discovered around London.
Rumors of a serial animal killer ran wild.
Police later determined the cause was not criminal.
transcript: Animal lovers and the press believed a sadistic killer was at large, but a lengthy investigation pointed toward scavenging by urban foxes. The episode explores moral panic and media responsibility.

title: The Bathtub Killer (Part 2)
summary: Continues the Texas Bathtub Killer investigation with new evidence, additional survivor accounts, and the killer’s conviction.
utterances: New cases, connected by forensics, opened up unresolved crimes.
The killer’s methods escalated over time.
The families’ advocacy was key to prosecution.
transcript: As more survivors came forward, the Bathtub Killer’s crime pattern emerged. Advocacy efforts and changes to victim support laws followed, leading to greater awareness and support nationwide.

title: The Essex Wife Swap Murder
summary: Tells the bizarre tale of Stuart Lubbock’s death at a party hosted by British TV star Michael Barrymore.
utterances: Lubbock died under suspicious circumstances.
Rumors and media attention kept the case alive.
Celebrity and parties obscured the evidence.
transcript: Despite a media circus and several suspects, the case has never been solved. Public interest in the intersection of fame, excess, and mortality continues.

title: Road Rage Murder
summary: Focuses on a fatal road rage incident in the UK and its chilling escalation from argument to murder.
utterances: A minor traffic spat escalated to shocking violence.
The episode discusses the psychology behind road rage.
Events spiraled out of control in seconds.
transcript: Random confrontations on the road result in unpredictable violence. The show probes the mindset behind these instant escalations and the tragic aftermath for victims’ families.

title: The Tragic Case of Gemma Hayter
summary: Explores the abuse and 2010 murder of a vulnerable, learning-disabled woman in Rugby, England.
utterances: Gemma was targeted by people she believed to be her friends.
Systemic failures failed to protect her.
The brutal crime forced social care reform.
transcript: Gemma Hayter's case exposed gaps in adult social services. Her faith in others became her undoing, raising questions about how society safeguards those at risk.

title: Killer Couples: Fred & Rose West
summary: Examines the crimes of Britain’s most notorious killer couple, who murdered multiple young women over decades.
utterances: Fred and Rose West buried their victims at 25 Cromwell Street.
Their family life hid unimaginable horror.
The case exposed decades of abuse and murder.
transcript: From child abuse to mass murder, the story of the Wests chills even the most hardened detectives. The remains recovered from their home suggested far more than the public ever suspected.

title: The Mystery of Suzy Lamplugh
summary: Dissects one of the UK's most well-known missing person cases and the investigation into potential serial suspects.
utterances: Estate agent Suzy Lamplugh vanished on a routine client meeting.
Her case led to changes in lone-worker policy for women.
To this day, no one knows what happened to her.
transcript: Suzy’s high-profile disappearance captured Britain’s attention, spawning decades of theories, but no solid answers. The episode discusses the impact her case had on safety awareness nationwide.
